For something that isn't related to accelerator resources, that makes no sense to me. Further, it complicates the cleanup path. I don't see you cleaning up these ARQs if network or block device stuff fails, and if you make it through all of that but we don't get the event (in time) from cyborg, you will raise a generic exception and not (AFAICT) clean up all the block device and network mess that you made.

Basically, I'm saying that unless the binding operation is a very long task, none of it should be done async like this, and if it is, I would tend to thing we should/could do that either before or after all the network and block device stuff, not in parallel, just for simplicity of doing the cleanup.

I put up this:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/695985/

Which will allow us to kick off the process from conductor like we originally discussed. It will allow us to make this a lot cleaner and less impactful. If the bind process is started from conductor, then in compute all we need to do is the following (pseudocode):

 with self.virtapi.wait_for_instance_event(instance, arq_events, deadline=timeout):
     early_events = check_for_binding_completed(instance, arq_events)
     self.virtapi.exit_wait_early(early_events)

If the event(s) haven't come yet, early_events will be empty, and we will wait for them as you would expect. If they *have* already come, we will return the names of the events and the exit will cause us to proceed immediately. The check_for_binding_completed() merely needs to poll cyborg once to see if binding is done for some/all of the expected ARQs. By doing that single poll within the waiting context, we know we're setup to receive the event before the poll, and after the poll, we know whether or not we need to wait or not.

I would recommend that we move that from build_resources where you have it here to be closer to the actual spawn (or perhaps in the virt driver to get overlap with the image download).

Make sense?

Sounds like the bind needs to be kicked off a tad later, after the host is associated with the instance.

> Not really. This would happen with any device when Cyborg can
 > determine that no device prep is needed. For example, if an FPGA

Ack, this is good to note. We don't want the race to exist anyway, but it's good to note a non-fake situation where we'll get nearly instantaneous bind completion.

> Yes, I could make the notification as a best effort in Cyborg --
 > try it once and not fail the binding itself if it fails.

Only if it fails with this specific condition, which you can determine via HTTP 207 + event['code'] 422.

 > Are you saying this is the entire solution?

Yes.

 > In most cases (all
 > cases with the fake driver, and many/most cases with real drivers),
 > the notification will get lost.

The point is, that's what we want. The "lost" events are among the ones that will be canceled via exit_wait_early.

For completeness, there are three good paths. When binding completes...

1) ...before the instance lands on the compute: The event is rejected with 422. We enter wait_for_instance_event and query cyborg, which tells us the binding is complete, so we exit_wait_early.

2) ...after the instance lands on compute, but before we enter wait_for_instance_event: The event is accepted and sent to the compute, which ignores it. We enter wait_for_instance_event and query cyborg, which tells us the binding is complete, so we exit_wait_early.

3) ...after we enter wait_for_instance_event: We queried cyborg and found the binding was *not* complete, so we didn't exit_wait_early. Once the binding completes, the event is emitted and wait_for_instance_event exits.

 > Secondly, to elaborate on the pseudocode:

Right, you figured all of this out, but yes, instance.host isn't set until the compute is sure it's going to get it. That's problematic in lots of areas, but it's also our sign that the instance is staying. I'm guessing that this only really happens with a fake cyborg driver because it completes immediately, right? Still, that leaves a race even with a real driver.

Moving the bind until after we've set instance.host makes it very late in the process, which is what we're trying to avoid. Also, making cyborg queue and retry the event seems too much to ask, IMHO. Nova would have a hard time doing that, and I don't doubt cyborg would as well.

One option is to just have cyborg not freak out about the 422 when sending the event, since we know we're asking it to do the work early and it may complete before we're ready. A 404 means the instance doesn't exist or was deleted mid-flight. 422 means "Cyborg won" but that's not really a problem.

> Can the cyborg side just retry on that 422 until the event is
 > accepted?

We started with Nova polling on Cyborg, which was not considered an optimal solution. By the same token, Cyborg polling on Nova is not the best solution either.

> I'm guessing that this only really happens

Yes, Cyborg sends one notification per instance (for all its ARQs), when all of those ARQs for that instance have completed binding (successfully or otherwise). If all completed successfully, the event notification status for the instance is 'completed'; if one or more have failed, the status is failure.

That is designed to forestall exactly this type of complication.

This is an upgrade breakage as it currently sits. If the nova control plane is new, and cyborg agent is running on the compute, we would be fooled into doing this work and then calling off to a potentially-old n-cpu service, which isn't going to do anything we're expecting.

Ideally we would bump the RPC version and communicate our intent directly and explicitly. However, at a minimum we need to make sure that we don't assume that it's going to happen and either arrange to never select an old compute, or check for it and explode ahead of time. It sounds like the preference for minimum accounting for this possibility is to have compute export a trait indicating that it can do cyborg stuff, which we can chuck into the scheduling request (if we have accels to do) to filter out computes without that capability. Cyborg can also use that to notice when computes aren't yet new enough to handle having accelerator inventory underneath.

> I am open to updating Cyborg to query this trait before publishing
 > nested RPs.

++

 > * Have the current patch series add that trait to each device
 > profile request group coming from Cyborg (so Placement gets queried
 > with it).

FWIW, I still don't like this.

But if you're going to do it, you can't add the trait to the device profile request groups, because that would cause Placement to look for it in the accel RPs, and that's not where it is. You want Placement to look for it in the root RP. Prior to Placement 1.35, you would have had to hack that into the unsuffixed request group, which sucks. But with 1.35, you can use the root_required queryparam -- this is what it's designed for.

As of this writing, we're doing GET /a_c at 1.34, but bumping it to 1.35 is a pretty easy patch. See e.g. [1] (ignore utils.py, test_report_client.py, and test_utils.py).

no it does not make sense because you should not have the treat_smartnic_ports function adding or removing ports or calling os-vif.

nova via its virtdirer and os-vif manages the l1 state of network backend. netuon should be managing only the l2+ configuration only.

in the case of an ironic deployment then the ironic virt driver in nova or the ironic code should be using os-vif to manage the l1 config.

in the virt driver case that would involve extending
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/virt/ironic/driver.py#L1535-L1642
to invoke os-vif to plug and unplug the interface.

alternately you could have done the integration in the ironic side. doing this in neutron however breaks the mental model of by making the neutron agent responsible for l1 configuration.

I don't think this is related directly to what this patch is trying to solve.

the approved direction today is that ovs agent shall delegate the L1 operations to os-vif like nova does since there is no nova entity running on smartNIC.

The smartNIC use case (currently baremetal only) which is implemented is the local one, where ovs agent runs *on* smartNIC. (it is the only openstack entity currently present on SmartNIC)

also i think you could use ironic with and without nova according to [1].

In addition opening another communication channel (directly to ovsdb on SmartNIC) also may compromise security, not an expert here in any way, just an opinion.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/ironic/latest/install/standalone.html
you should not have needed to add this fucntion at all.

this is incorrect.

the agent should not be calling os-vif to do the pluging and unpluging. in the libvirt case the virt driver will call os-vif in the ironic case nova currently calls the ironic api but it would have been correct to call os-vif in that case or for ironic to do so to manage pluggin the interfaces.

similarly you should not need to have this function.

the nova compute manager will call unplug_vifs on the virt dirver, in the libvirt case it will call os-vif to unplug th port form ovs and in the iroinc driver it calls the ironic api. that should have been either modifited to call os-vif or ironic should have been modified to call os-vif.

tripleo_ansible/playbooks/molecule-tripl.message:
nit: we should name the playbook

  - name: TripleO IPA Post
    hosts: all
    ...

Putting log files into /tmp is a security breach; we should not do that.
Logs go in /var/log and have proper permissions (not world readable at least).

This is for retrieving logs for the tripleo-ansible-centos-7-molecule-tripleo_ipa job, the whole IPA installation, which is located in /tmp/ipa-data is temporary.
It is readable to anyone reviewing the patch, example:
 https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/0db6c643af294b7f80cdf450739e2eb5/logs
This isn't tripleo specific; and like I said, putting logs in /tmp isn't secure. Even if it's only used by CI, we still ship that playbook and someone could use it in production by mistake.

This is copied over to the zuul.executor.log_root directory  for the purpose of debugging the CI job, so that it appears in https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/a5e70e7ea157489e8a879ac25bc05eac/log/ipaserver-install.log

This copy is not read by any automation, it's copied there regardless, "post-run", for humans (reviewers).

I don't know nearly enough about IPA, there might be a silent issue during the deployment that manifests itself in the logs, so the log is always there just in case.

If it fails, there can be lots of reasons, like changes in Linux/GNU distribution versions, etc... The log will usually contain a traceback and more useful info.

Without the log, it's hard to search for a solution or know what failed.

This is specific to the tripleo-ansible molecule tests and how Zuul handles logs. It is called in zuul.d/molecule.yaml. It can be removed, since it is not essential, but it helps to see this log when there is a CI error on the patch.

The path of the temporary deployment is currently hardcoded in tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_ipa/molecule/default/prepare.yml

Placing it in some other place than /tmp will end up creating files in unexpected places and filling up disk space when molecule tests are run.

Turns out that SM clears (knowledge of) previous fault at 40 seconds after restart rather than 60. Meaning that if a monitored service has an issue where it runs for 40 seconds or more before it fails/exits, then SM will just restart it over and over without swacting ; no escalation.

meta/main.yml.message:
This should not be a meta-dependency - we run the role using include_role, not through the meta-dependency implementation in ansible (which runs the python-venv-build role prior to running the os_tempest role).

Ansible role meta-reps are useful for pre-loading libraries/modules like config_template, but not very good for expressing roles it depends on.

@kaifeng, the way I read the docs
https://jinja.palletsprojects.com/en/2.10.x/api/#autoescaping

one must explicitly use

  autoescape=select_autoescape()

when declaring the environment for this to be enabled only for html and such docs. We in this line however explicitly enable it - for everything.

What breaks is any attempt to pass a kernel param that e.g. might need quotes (like URL that may contain =), and so when one sets smth like in ironic.conf:

  pxe_append_params = url="http://foo.bar"

it is now rendered to

  url="http://foo.bar"

and fail to be parsed by kernel

neutron/services/trunk/plugin.py.message:
Suggestion:

I know this sounds risky, but we should do a bulk update without using the plugin but the DB object itself (not the OVO). "device_id" will be <empty string> or the trunk ID. Can't be any other value (there are many checks in the code taking care of this that we are going to skip now).

Risks:
- We skip the plugin checks for "device_id".
- We don't raise any notification. That means we can, eventually, break the compatibility with a current or a future extension reading the port update (in this particular case, the "device_id").
- A multiple register writing operation is prone to fail (but we can retry).

The direct query update, using the port IDs (the "device_id" is the same for all of them), is a very fast operation. This will solve the rally problems we have right now.

sushy/resources/system/system.py.message: Wont this cause backward in-compatibility as default value is changed?

It will, but may be that's OK...? I have two thoughts:

* The whole point of this change is to stop touching boot parameters (including boot frequency) unless explicitly asked
* I have a gut feeling that BMCs are not overly consistent when it comes to boot options - some seem to ignoring boot frequency, some are failing when it's given...

If we want to preserve backward compatibility, the only idea that I have is to introduce another variable and eventually deprecate `enabled`.

WDYT?
OK, here's my take on that.

At the midcycle, I believe we described the implementation in set_system_boot_source() this proposed change effectively modifies as passing PUT data in a PATCH request. We seemed to agree the PATCH request is reasonable, but the data should be changed to PATCH data which contains only the parameters which have changed. I believe this does not do that. If the caller passes in arguments which represent no change, they are still provided in the data.

I see an openstack/ironic change which depends on this sushy change, https://review.opendev.org/#/c/711118/, checks if the desired value is different from the current value -- https://review.opendev.org/#/c/711118/2/ironic/drivers/modules/redfish/management.py@135. Might that logic be better placed in this method so callers do not need to concern themselves with that?

> At the midcycle, I believe we described the implementation in
 > set_system_boot_source() this proposed change effectively modifies
 > as passing PUT data in a PATCH request. We seemed to agree the
 > PATCH request is reasonable, but the data should be changed to
 > PATCH data which contains only the parameters which have changed. I
 > believe this does not do that. If the caller passes in arguments
 > which represent no change, they are still provided in the data.


That's s very good point! After the conversation we've had, I went on to check how it goes with the official fishiness - it appears, that the fishy way of PATCHing is this [1].

 
 > I see an openstack/ironic change which depends on this sushy
 > change, https://review.opendev.org/#/c/711118/, checks if the
 > desired value is different from the current value --
 > https://review.opendev.org/#/c/711118/2/ironic/drivers/modules/redfish/management.py@135.
 > Might that logic be better placed in this method so callers do not
 > need to concern themselves with that?


I thought about that as well! My problem here is that this conditional update is inherently racy (if more than one client is operating on the same BMC, or BMC changes its state between GET and PATCH). Therefore I am not certain that we (as sushy) should make this risky decision rather than to let the client decide what's the best approach for it.

> I forgot to paste the spec [1]:
 > 
 > Changes to one or more properties within the resource addressed by
 > the request Uri are sent in the request body. Properties not
 > specified in the request body are not directly changed by the PATCH
 > request.
 > 
 > 1. http://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/DSP0266_1.5.0.html#update-patch-a-id-update-patch-a-


To provide context, I have copied my earlier, context-free response here.

Thank you for the reference. My read of it is that the decision we reached at the midcycle, include only the changed properties in the PATCH request's data, complies with the standard.

Do you agree?

I think at the mid-cycle we thought we should only include the changes that we want to modify because that would be easier on the BMCs (which are not always  super reliable and support performant). I agree with that, or at least that is what I gathered from that discussion.

At that time we thought we should do in RFC6902 way, because that's how REST APIs tend to work. Later on it turned out that Redfish spec does not suggest to use RFC6902.

This patch implements non-RFC6902 way of including only modified attributes in PATCH.

> I thought about that as well! My problem here is that this
 > conditional update is inherently racy (if more than one client is
 > operating on the same BMC, or BMC changes its state between GET and
 > PATCH). Therefore I am not certain that we (as sushy) should make
 > this risky decision rather than to let the client decide what's the
 > best approach for it.


I do not see any risk here. AFAIU, the system boot options aspect of the Redfish RESTful API is inherently racy. Immediately after Client One PATCHes it, Client Two could overwrite those settings with a PATCH of its own. There is no way to atomically set the system boot options and boot the system with them.

Since there are no management roles and every client has access to everything, one could say that two clients managing a server at the same time is fundamentally broken. I am not sure we should concern ourselves about that possibility.

A parameter could be added to set_system_boot_options() which indicates whether or not to include unchanged properties. Just a thought.

I forgot to paste the spec [1]:

    Changes to one or more properties within the resource addressed by the request Uri are sent in the request body. Properties not specified in the request body are not directly changed by the PATCH request. 

1. http://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/DSP0266_1.5.0.html#update-patch-a-id-update-patch-a-

> > I thought about that as well! My problem here is that this
 > > conditional update is inherently racy (if more than one client is
 > > operating on the same BMC, or BMC changes its state between GET
 > and
 > > PATCH). Therefore I am not certain that we (as sushy) should make
 > > this risky decision rather than to let the client decide what's
 > the
 > > best approach for it.
 > 
 > 
 > I do not see any risk here. AFAIU, the system boot options aspect
 > of the Redfish RESTful API is inherently racy. Immediately after
 > Client One PATCHes it, Client Two could overwrite those settings
 > with a PATCH of its own. There is no way to atomically set the
 > system boot options and boot the system with them.

Yes, this is exactly the risk I am worrying about. I do agree that there seems to be no clear solution to avoid this racing.

On the other hand, may be many clients - one BMC is a legitimate case? If it was not, may be we'd have a word in the spec or some kind of locking mechanism built in?

 > Since there are no management roles and every client has access to
 > everything, one could say that two clients managing a server at the
 > same time is fundamentally broken. I am not sure we should concern
 > ourselves about that possibility.

May be that depends on the site...?  Some installations may somehow ensure one client - one BMC relationship, others may allow one-to-many. In the latter case  sushy should not invoke this read-check-write logic, but do just unconditional write.

 > A parameter could be added to set_system_boot_options() which
 > indicates whether or not to include unchanged properties. Just a
 > thought.

Well, that's a way, but I am still not sure it's justified given our murky understanding of the use-cases...

Also, we have 3 distinct parameters in that method, will that new parameter control all three options at once or each individually?

Obviously it is likely best for the client to try and decide that and also assert that as needed. I see this potentially being problematic if there is wholesale behavior differences, but the key is really trying to get the BMC to honor the setting changes.

 > >
 > > I do not see any risk here. AFAIU, the system boot options aspect

 > > Client One PATCHes it, Client Two could overwrite those settings

 > Yes, this is exactly the risk I am worrying about. I do agree that

 > kind of locking mechanism built in?

 > > everything, one could say that two clients managing a server at
 > the
 > > same time is fundamentally broken. I am not sure we should
 > concern
 > > ourselves about that possibility.
 > 
 > May be that depends on the site...?  Some installations may somehow
 > ensure one client - one BMC relationship, others may allow
 > one-to-many. In the latter case  sushy should not invoke this
 > read-check-write logic, but do just unconditional write.
 > 

I am +1000 with Richard on that it is invalid configuration to to manage the same distinct system with two separate management platforms concurrently. We simply cannot support that operation and the operating model which ironic an support is as it is basically the sole authoritative source of truth.

So trying to build library internal locking doesn't seem to apply nor would actually fix this issue because the race would still be achievable. Basically, this sort of race exists with most APIs anyway, all we can do is try to cope our best with the caller of the library (ironic, or any other program.)

Also likely worth stressing that some vendors have explicitly stated their redfish BMC address is a proxy frontend to the backend API which doesn't update for 30-60 seconds. That is logic we can't represent handling for and is a huge potential race. There really is no defending against that and trying to prevent an operator from misusing the APIs.

 > > A parameter could be added to set_system_boot_options() which
 > > indicates whether or not to include unchanged properties. Just a
 > > thought.
 > 
 > Well, that's a way, but I am still not sure it's justified given
 > our murky understanding of the use-cases...
 > 
 > Also, we have 3 distinct parameters in that method, will that new
 > parameter control all three options at once or each individually?

I'm not exactly a fan of different parameters and sending blank updates, but maybe it is warranted except only by BMC design/behavior.  Perhaps the thing is the caller of the library should be knowing when to do things one at a time?

let's add a note to remove this at some point
Maybe after next release?

gbpservice/neutron/plugins/ml2plus/drive.message:
I see the failure on a HPB workflow - so will need to qualify the network type a bit more carefully - the failure case is when we trigger port binding for a OpFlex type net with a non opflex agent.

We really need to qualify the provider vlan type network in failing test case the binding info looks as below:

[EndpointBindingInfo(host=u'host1', level=0, network_type=u'opflex', physical_network=u'physnet1', segmentation_id=None),
 EndpointBindingInfo(host=u'host1', level=1, network_type=u'vlan', physical_network=u'physnet1', segmentation_id=1063)]

Perhaps a quick discussion and I can tweak this in the cleanest way possible.

I think we've finally concluded that we will do physdom bindings in all cases where there the opflex agent is bound using a VLAN segment, so I guess basing this on the segment's network type makes sense. In that case, we need a flag in the RPC response indicating the agent that this is a "pass-through" binding where the opflex agent will not enforce any policies. I'm pretty sure we don't need 95% of the RPC response details in that case, not just the EPG, since the agent won't be doing policy enforcement or NAT or DHCP or metadata or anything. Not sure if security groups get enforced in this case.

I think it is important that we only allow these "pass-through" bindings in cases where the VLAN segment has a physnet corresponding to a physdom that the agent has access to, probably based on a bridge mappings attribute in the agent_info. I wonder if we should prevent these sorts of bindings in cases where NAT is expected, or if SGs cannot be enforced?

Finally, it seems we also want this sort of "pass-through" binding for ports on normal networks for which the SFC remapping of the network has been triggered. We need some way to determine this when processing the agent RPC, as the binding itself will be to the network's opflex segment. We also need to make sure notifications are sent to all involved ports whenever the SFC mapping gets triggerred or untriggered. I'm not sure that is currently being done.

Just to clarify - the above code change only pertains to the RPC, and not port binding, correct? I guess I'm asking as I wanted to understand whether this was a new bug introduced by this patch, or if that bug was already there (due to a previous patch being merged).

Thanks Bob. I do believe SG are enforced. 

Lets discuss a bit on the best way to enforce the physnet - physdom validation - if we can piggyback on some existing mechanic or introduce something new. I will reach out for a time to discuss.
I think this should be "For static VLAN type segments..."
I'm not sure what is meant by "trickle into" here. Is a comment even needed?
Thx Bob. Removed the block so moot.

We already include all the details of bottom bound segment in the RPC response. See lines 868-870 above. Given that, I don't think any changes to this file are necessary. We should keep the 'svi' flag as meaning that it is an SVI network. If the 'svi' flag is not set, the agent should decide what to do based on the 'network_type' that it is already passed.
Yes indeed - this is so obvious and clean. Thx - I wonder what I was thinking. :-) Done.

Please move this import up to between lines 28 and 29. The convention is that imports from the current repo are grouped together last. 

Actually the import of mock should probably be a separate group before the others, as that is a standard python library. As I understand it, there should be up to three groups of imports, each separated by a space. The first is standard python libs, the second is external non-standard python projects, and the third is the current project's repo.

neutron/services/ovn_l3/plugin.py.message:
I'm OK with this change. Actually, it's better to use the existing idl connection. Just two comments:

1) Can you create in the OVNMechanismDriver a property to make _nb_ovn and _sb_ovn public? This is just a nit
2) Both connections are enabled during "post_fork_initialize". Could be possible we can call _ovn and the connection is still not created? What could happens then? Shouldn't we check it?
In the original implementation, the idl connection is always created.

Ok, so _ovn/_sb_ovn don't get called until after post_fork_initialize is called. The earliest callers will be from schedule_unhosted_gateways() which is called either by the ChassisEvent which can't fire w/o a connection, and by the sync thread, which doesn't get initialized until after the connections.

Thanks for the review!

1) Yeah, but it's referenced a lot. I was hoping we could find a different way to reference it altogether since this feels really ugly and looking pretty deep into the ml2 stuff. Like the trunk driver, being created inside the mech driver, has a nice reference to plugin_driver. That sure would be nice. :p But I don't see anything similar for l3. I can change it, but it will make the patch uglier. :D 

2) The mech driver won't do anything (at least anything requiring ovn_client) until that is initialized, so I was thinking that the l3 plugin would probably be safe as well. But if not, since we have a reference to the mech driver now, we should be able to just wait on the driver._post_fork_event which exists specifically for this reason.
I don't like a bit this broken naming convention between nb_ovn and sb_ovn. For me it would be better just to rename this property to be _nb_ovn to be consistent with _sb_ovn.
Agreed. I generally try to keep aesthetic things like renaming, etc. in a separate patch just to simplify reviews and so if you have to revert a patch, you don't lose both changes.
